title: 108_hr1003
content: The "Meat and Poultry Inspection Accountability Act" may impose civil penalties for violations of meat and poultry inspection laws. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to assess civil penalties for violations of the Federal Meat Inspection Act or the Poultry Products Inspection Act. The maximum penalty for a violation is $100,000, taking into account factors such as the gravity of the violation, culpability, business size, and past offenses. Each violation and day of violation is considered a separate offense. The Secretary of Agriculture can assess civil penalties for violations of the Federal Meat Inspection Act or the Poultry Products Inspection Act. A person must be given notice and a hearing before a penalty is imposed. Judicial review of the penalty can only be done through a petition to the United States court of appeals within 30 days. The Secretary of Agriculture can assess civil penalties for violations of the Federal Meat Inspection Act or the Poultry Products Inspection Act. A person must be given notice and a hearing before a penalty is imposed. If the penalty is not paid after becoming final, the matter will be referred to the Attorney General for collection through a civil action in United States district court. The Secretary of Agriculture can impose civil penalties for violations of the Federal Meat Inspection Act or the Poultry Products Inspection Act. The order imposing the penalty is not subject to review. If the penalty is not paid, inspection services may be refused or withdrawn until payment is made. The Secretary may choose to assess a civil penalty instead of pursuing prosecution for violations. In addition to other remedies, civil penalties can be imposed on individuals, partnerships, corporations, associations, or other business units for violations. SEC. 3. FEDERAL FOOD, DRUG, AND COSMETIC ACT; CIVIL PENALTIES REGARDING MEAT AND POULTRY. Section 303 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include a new subsection imposing a civil penalty of up to $100,000 for violations related to meat or poultry. The penalty amount will be determined based on the gravity of the violation, degree of culpability, size and type of the business, and any prior offenses under the Act. This penalty is subject to the same provisions as civil penalties under subsection (g).
